item.title: Erika Kirk Takes on the Mantle of Leading Turning Point USA
item.description: The widow of Charlie Kirk promoted conciliation and portrayed her late husband as a seeker of dialogue.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: 5 Takeaways From the 2025 DealBook Summit
item.description: President Trump’s economic policies and artificial intelligence were among the central topics at the gathering of business and political leaders.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone, Brian O’Keefe and Bernhard Warner
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California, right, speaking to Andrew Ross Sorkin, Dealbook Editor at Large, at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Newsom Warns That Trump Is ‘Trying to Wreck This Country’
item.description: The California governor weighed in on the 2028 presidential election, and called out executives for “bending the knee” to President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Laurel Rosenhall
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: For MrBeast, YouTube Still Rules, but It’s Not Everything
item.description: The social media star has created a vast and varied business empire with big expansion plans.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jimmy Donaldson, known as MrBeast, at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday.

item.title: Netanyahu Says He Is Undaunted by Legal Woes at Home and Threats of Arrest by New York’s Mayor-Elect
item.description: Netanyahu says he is undaunted by Mamdani arrest threats or domestic legal woes
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel speaking at the DealBook conference in New York on Wednesday via video from Israel.

item.title: Prediction markets were part of the conversation at the DealBook Summit.
item.description: The platforms allow people to bet on political races and the Oscars. Could they also be good for policy
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

item.title: Spotify Wrapped Has Users Talking About Their ‘Listening Age’
item.description: The wrinkle in this year’s Spotify Wrapped release was an estimate of the user’s “listening age.” Some wore it like a badge of honor. Others made excuses.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher

item.title: National Park Service Will Close All Grand Canyon Hotels for Water Line Repairs
item.description: The National Park Service said seven hotels would temporarily close starting on Saturday after “significant breaks” in a crucial 12.5-mile water line.
item.dc:creator: Gabe Castro-Root
item.media:credit: Gabe Castro-Root/The New York Times
item.media:description: The South Rim of the Grand Canyon, which draws 90 percent of visitors to the national park, avoided damage from the wildfire that destroyed a historic lodge on the North Rim last summer.

item.title: Anthropic’s Dario Amodei Acknowledges Risks of Enormous Investment in A.I.
item.description: As he and his company pour tens of billions into new data centers, Dario Amodei said they face a “cone of uncertainty.”
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, chief executive of Anthropic, acknowledged that the enormous amounts of spending could come back to haunt at least some A.I. companies.

item.title: Executives say they are optimistic about the economy despite high costs.
item.description: A cooling labor market and economic softness in the United States haven’t prevented business leaders and policymakers from feeling positive about America’s prospects.
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times

item.title: Palantir’s CEO Defends Trump, Dismisses Concerns About Company’s Work With ICE.
item.description: Alex Karp also said he thought President Trump had “performed” on issues he cared about.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Alex Karp, the chief executive of Palantir, at the DealBook Summit on Wednesday.

item.title: GM Will Still Make Fuel Efficient Motors Despite Weaker Rules, CEO Mary Barra Says
item.description: But the chief executive, Mary Barra, added that the jury was still out on whether electric vehicles would become a major seller in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Every engine we invest in, we work to have a significant improvement” in fuel economy and emissions, Mary Barra said.

item.title: Bessent Defends Trump’s Use of Tariffs, Says They Are Not Fueling Inflation
item.description: The Treasury secretary said that import levies were not fueling inflation.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent in conversation with Andrew Ross Sorkin at The New York Times DealBook Summit on Wednesday.

item.title: Bubbles are front of mind for speakers at the DealBook Summit.
item.description: Many market analysts have expressed concern about private credit loans, including fears of a future crisis should the market crumble.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Spending on data centers, which are filled with Nvidia chips, was a driving force behind the U.S. economic growth this year.

item.title: BlackRock and Coinbase Chiefs Dismiss Fears of a Coming Crypto Winter
item.description: Larry Fink and Brian Armstrong haven’t always agreed on crypto, but the business leaders’ embrace of the asset has helped bring it into the mainstream.
item.dc:creator: Niko Gallogly
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Ross Sorkin speaking to Brian Armstrong, chief executive of Coinbase, and Larry Fink, the chief executive of BlackRock.

item.title: Hong Kong’s Response to Deadly Fire Shows China’s Play Book in Action
item.description: In a sign of China’s role in the city, officials have tried to stamp out calls for accountability over a catastrophe that killed at least 159 people.
item.dc:creator: Li Yuan
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: After last week’s deadly fire at a residential complex, Hong Kong warned its residents against using it to “cause chaos.”

item.title: Shoppers Turn to Discounts and Debt, but Not Just for Holidays
item.description: Consumers are focusing on value and financing purchases to complete their shopping lists.
item.dc:creator: Emmett Lindner

item.title: Taiwan’s President Warns That China’s Military Aggression Is Growing
item.description: President Lai Ching-te is aiming to invest an additional $40 billion in military spending to deter China.
item.dc:creator: Niko Gallogly
item.media:credit: Yimou Lee/Reuters
item.media:description: President Lai Ching-te of Taiwan speaking last week.

item.title: Private Employers Cut Jobs in November, in Latest Sign of a Slowdown
item.description: Data from ADP, a payroll processor, is getting added attention because of delays in official statistics caused by the government shutdown.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman
item.media:credit: Akilah Townsend for The New York Times
item.media:description: An employment fair in Chicago in October. The labor market lost over 30,000 jobs last month.

item.title: The DealBook Summit has interviewed top leaders since 2012.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced and Sarah Kessler
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Andrew Ross Sorkin interviewing the Goldman Sachs chief executive Lloyd Blankfein at the first DealBook Summit in 2012.

item.title: Last year’s DealBook Summit featured Bill Clinton, Sam Altman and Jeff Bezos.
item.description: Artificial intelligence, inflation and the incoming Trump administration were big topics of conversation.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler

item.title: Dario Amodei, Scott Bessent, Erika Kirk Among Speakers at DealBook Summit
item.description: Andrew Ross Sorkin will interview some of the most powerful people from Wall Street, Silicon Valley and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler
item.media:credit: From left, Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times; Fabrice Coffrini/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images; Pool photo by Roy Rochlin
item.media:description: From left, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, Dario Amodei and Erika Kirk.

item.title: Here’s the latest on the 2025 DealBook Summit.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Kessler

item.title: What to Expect at Today’s DealBook Summit: Full Speaker Lineup
item.description: Scott Bessent, Erika Kirk, Gavin Newsom, Dario Amodei, Mary Barra, Alex Karp, MrBeast, Lai Ching-te and Larry Fink are among the big names speaking.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe and Ian Mount
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Leaders in politics, business and culture will gather in New York for the DealBook Summit today to speak with The Times’s Andrew Ross Sorkin. He interviewed Jeff Bezos of Amazon at last year’s event.

item.title: Nature Retracts Study Predicting Catastrophic Climate Toll
item.description: While growing evidence shows that carbon emissions are harming the economy, the journal Nature found that an outlier paper had deep flaws.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis
item.category: Potsdam Institute for Climate Impact Research
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Fed Pick Puts Pressure on Bessent to Deliver for Trump
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, who is leading the search for the next Federal Reserve chair, could face President Trump’s wrath if the person chosen does not quickly lower interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport and Colby Smith
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: If the next Federal Reserve chair proves to be less than compliant with President Trump’s wishes, Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent could take the blame.

item.title: Bitcoin’s Predicted Sky-High Prices Have Not Panned Out
item.description: Bitcoin has plunged more than 30 percent and Ether is down around 40 percent in recent months, as gains from President Trump’s pro-crypto policies evaporated.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Kailyn Rhone
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Ahead of Tariff Ruling, Businesses Race to Secure Refunds
item.description: The Supreme Court has not yet ruled on the legality of President Trump’s sweeping tariffs, but some companies aren’t waiting to try to secure a speedy and substantial payout.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ana Swanson
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: A ruling against President Trump could force his administration to pay back the roughly $200 billion it has collected in duties since the start of the year.

item.title: How to Ski: A Beginner’s Guide
item.description: What to know about gear, ski passes, classes and more.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:credit: Weston Wei

item.title: A Devastating Fire Has Fueled a National Security Crackdown in Hong Kong
item.description: The authorities quickly arrested critics demanding accountability, signaling an expansive use of the security law to silence dissent over nonpolitical tragedies.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Alexandra Stevenson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising from a residential complex in Tai Po, Hong Kong, in November.

item.title: Smartmatic and Fox Urge Judge to Decide Defamation Case
item.description: The case centers on false vote-rigging claims broadcast by Fox News during the 2020 U.S. presidential election.
item.dc:creator: Katie Robertson
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Fox News ticker in Manhattan. Smartmatic contends its reputation was smeared and its business severely harmed by statements by Fox News hosts.

item.title: New Pentagon Press Corps Test-Drives the Briefing Room
item.description: A new group of media figures was given credentials to cover the Pentagon after many traditional news outlets refused to sign its new reporting rules.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wemple
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: An aerial view of the Pentagon, in October.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Foundation Grows to $14 Billion, but Gives Little to Outsiders
item.description: The philanthropy has become one of America’s biggest, but most of its giving went to charities closely tied to the world’s richest man.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer and David A. Fahrenthold
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk’s foundation gave $370 million last year to a nonprofit in Texas led by his top aide that operates an elementary school in a rural area where many of Mr. Musk’s employees live.

item.title: India Orders a Tracking App to Be Installed in All Smartphones
item.description: The government said the rules were needed to prevent theft and other crime. Its opponents and privacy activists regard the app as a tool of mass surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Pragati K.B.
item.media:credit: Manish Swarup/Associated Press
item.media:description: The Sanchar Saathi app on a mobile phone.

item.title: What Michael Dell’s Blockbuster Donation Means for Philanthropy
item.description: Michael Dell and his wife, Susan Dell, plan to give away billions of dollars to fund investment accounts for children in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Niko Gallogly, Brian O’Keefe, Nicholas Kulish, Ian Mount and Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Jack Plunkett/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michael and Susan Dell, seen here in 2014, said they would pledge $6.25 billion to fund investment accounts for roughly 25 million children.

item.title: Kalshi, a Prediction Market, Raises $1 Billion in New Round
item.description: The fund-raising effort, the company’s third this year, values it at $11 billion, and comes amid stiff competition in the increasingly popular industry.
item.dc:creator: Michael J. de la Merced
item.media:credit: Marshall Scheuttle for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kalshi gained mainstream recognition with its election-related betting contracts, but has since grown to offer wagers on sports, the weather and more.

item.title: What to Know About Trump Accounts for Children and Eligibility After Dell Donation
item.description: Next year, Michael and Susan Dell plan to move $250 into the new Trump accounts of millions of children under 10. You’ll need to live in the right ZIP code.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber and Nicholas Kulish
item.media:credit: Joan Cros/NurPhoto via Getty Images
item.media:description: Michael Dell, chairman and chief executive of Dell Technologies, and his wife, Susan, announced that they were donating $6.25 billion to benefit about 25 million children.

item.title: 120,000 Home Cameras Were Hacked for Sexual Videos, South Korean Police Say
item.description: The authorities arrested four people this week in the latest turn in the country’s effort to stop exploitative recordings.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: Residential buildings in Seoul, the South Korean capital, in August. Four people were arrested over the infiltration of 120,000 home security cameras, police said.

item.title: Michael and Susan Dell Pledge $6 Billion in Investment ‘Trump Accounts’ for Children
item.description: The tech billionaire and his wife hope other philanthropists follow their $6 billion lead in expanding the reach of soon-to-be-created “Trump accounts.”
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Kulish
item.media:credit: Evan Vucci/Associated Press
item.media:description: Michael Dell, the head of Dell Technologies, said that giving directly to children echoed his early business model of direct computer sales.

item.title: Beta Will Sell Motors to Another Electric Aircraft Company
item.description: The deal with a company owned by Embraer gives Beta Technologies an additional source of revenue as it develops its own electric aircraft.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.category: Embraer - Empresa Brasileira de Aeronautica SA
item.media:credit: Kylie Cooper/Reuters
item.media:description: An electric aircraft made by Beta Technologies, a start-up based in Vermont.

item.title: The New York Times Marks Centennial of Bureau in China
item.description: The death of Sun Yat-sen, the suppression of a labor protest, and a visit to China by a member of the Roosevelt family led to the bureau’s opening in 1925.
item.dc:creator: Keith Bradsher
item.media:credit: George Alexanderson/The New York Times
item.media:description: The large New York Times bureau in Shanghai was in this building, a Chinese newspaper’s headquarters, in 1947.

item.title: Apple’s A.I. Chief, John Giannandrea, Is Retiring
item.description: John Giannandrea, hired from Google, is leaving after the release of a new Siri was postponed. Apple has fallen behind rivals in efforts to develop A.I. products.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - SEPTEMBER 19: Google's Senior VP of Engineering John Giannandrea speaks onstage during TechCrunch Disrupt SF 2017 at Pier 48 on September 19, 2017 in San Francisco, California. (Photo by Steve Jennings/Getty Images for TechCrunch)
item.media:description: Steve Jennings/Getty Images for TechCrunch

item.title: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader Join Forces to Form New Art Gallery
item.description: Pace, Di Donna and David Schrader of Sotheby’s are collaborating on an Upper East Side space that will focus on secondary market sales.
item.dc:creator: Robin Pogrebin
item.media:credit: via Pace Gallery, Photo by Thomas Loof; George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.media:description: The exterior of Pace Gallery, New York (left), and the Di Donna Gallery (right). They will merge into a new location on the Upper East Side, and David Schrader will join the leaders of those galleries in a new venture.

item.title: TSA Imposes $45 Fee for Travelers Without REAL ID Starting February 2026
item.description: As of February, passengers without the government-approved identity card will be required to pay for alternative screening at U.S. airports.
item.dc:creator: Christine Chung
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: A T.S.A. worker checks a traveler’s ID at the international airport in Oakland, Calif.

item.title: To Avoid Pharma Tariffs, U.K. Agrees to Trump’s Demand to Pay More for Drugs
item.description: President Trump has complained that wealthy countries like Britain pay too little for drugs, leading America to bear much of the burden of the costs of medicines.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Robbins and Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Jonathan Nackstrand/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A lab run by the drugmaker AstraZeneca. President Trump has complained that wealthy European countries pay too little for medicines.
